html:
Apple Store May Open Mid June

Last week, GM reported a rumor that the Apple Store was coming along pretty well and that it could even meet the original May opening. It turns out that was a little optimistic.

An Evening with Chefs Eric Ripert and Anthony Bourdain

The Warner Theater was full of foodies, travel TV enthusiasts and fans on Friday night as internationally known Chefs Eric Ripert and Anthony Bourdain joined MIX 107.3’s Tommy McFly for an evening of unscripted

Walk of Shame

Friday Glover Park’s Gin and Tonic hosted cover band,

The Wildest Culinary Celebration in Town

Over a thousand guests enjoyed a beautiful spring evening at The National Zoo sampling delicious fare from than 100 of DC’s best restaurants including Michel Richard’s Central, Georgetown newcomer Morso and Morton’s Steakhouse at Z

FAIR Fund Presents Pearls of Purpose at the Austrian Embassy

More than 300 guests gathered at the Austrian Embassy Thursday evening for the fourth annual “Pearls of Purpose," a program to support the FAIR Fund's work to stop the sex and labor trafficking of youth worldwide.

More about the housing numbers...

I sift through statistics from several different sources, and as I have mentioned before, I try to make a distinction between national and regional stats, and local stats.

CityShopGirl SATC Party at Bar Dupont

Kelly Collis Fredrick’s CityShopGirl hosted a cocktail party at Bar Dupont on Wednesday evening to celebrate the release of the upcoming Sex and the City 2 movie which debuts next week.

Feed Your Children Well

Not all of us had the healthiest diet in the world when we were kids. I can safely say that in my youth, I considered the major food groups to be Oreos, French fries, double-decker fast food burgers and ice cream—always eaten with pretzels where I come from.

Cross Dressing

Manolo-heeled women sip Sancerre at a home jewelry show while trying on necklaces—some three strands deep in pearls or colorful stones of citrine, amethyst and turquoise. Hanging from the end of many of the necklaces are bejeweled crosses.

Tree Week: The Do’s

As promised Monday, today for Tree Week GM will address the “do’s” of caring for our precious street trees.

White House Secretary Hopes to Dish

White House secretary-turned-journalist Lillian Cox has plenty of secrets to share from her days spent in Washington, D.C.

Road Trippin'

On Friday I delivered my sweet but stressed Norwegian Elkhound, Nina to a trainer in Virginia for a much-needed behavioral boot camp.

The Poetry of Real Estate

Can we learn anything specifically about the real estate market or business from a poem? I couldn't think of any poems I had read about real estate...aside from the limerick-like doggerel I have written myself, or heard from other real estate practitioners.

Welcome to Tree Week

Tree-lined streets are one of the most often mentioned features that people associate with Georgetown. And it’s for good reason. Georgetown wouldn’t be what it is were it denuded of its beautiful tree canopy.

Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy? Kitty Kelley, Part I

She is notorious, glamorous, maligned and hugely successful. A controversial literary icon, she is simultaneously a beloved Georgetown neighbor who can be counted on to support neighborhood causes. Needy causes.

Vinyasa Flow Here I Come

By the time you finish this article, I will have rolled up my new yoga mat (I always start with the accessories) and be headed to my first yoga class.

Those pesky numbers!

They say numbers don't lie, and I suppose if numbers could speak for themselves that might be the case.

Into the Mouths of Babes

"When did food become age-appropriate?" Nancy Tringali Piho, author of "My Two-Year Old Eats Octopus"asked rhetorically as we savored Chef Michel Richard's pearl pasta risotto.

Robbed in Georgetown, Part V: Judith

Robbed in Georgetown is a multi-part series describing a frequent crime in an unexpected place. This is the final excerpt. Links to Parts I to IV are below.

The event at The Ritz Hotel on Monday night looked more like a beauty pageant than a fundraiser for Breast Cancer. Eighteen Newsbabes participated. Here are a few takes...

May Georgetown Have This Barnes Dance?

It was reported last week that DDOT is planning on bringing the Barnes Dance to Chinatown, specifically the intersection of 7th and H.

Scents & Sensibility

One of the best thing about spring and early summer

is the smells. Honeysuckle, lavender, gardenia ... mmm.

Besides encouraging my obsession for flowers, the scents of

the season have kick-started a bit of a love affair with

Ball on the Mall Benefits The National Mall

The L’Enfant Society’s “Ball on the Mall” Saturday night was the spectacular site of D.C.’s young philanthropists dining and dancing under the up-lit Washington Monument with the U.S. Capitol shining in the distance.

All Politicians Local at Social Safeway

D.C. Councilmember Jack Evans, a longtime customer of the Georgetown store, admits that, like others he used to pace the aisles Friday nights hoping to meet someone special at the old Social Safeway. Many did. For Evans, it was risky.

Pamper Mom with a Georgetown Pedi

Hey, how about something for Mom that she really wants this Mother's Day -- a mani/pedi just steps away at the corner of M Street and Potomac on the 2nd floor above Subway.

A Mother’s Day--and Night

I’m asleep, but feel a presence hovering next to the bed.

“Mommy, I threw up,” my youngest daughter says before I can open my eyes.

ANC Round Up: Holy Crepe Edition

The ANC met for its May session last night. Heavy on liquor discussions and mercifully short on residential permit issues, the meeting was a lively one. But are you even reading this or are just thinking about how much you’d love some peach crepes right now?

Fillmore School Building Reportedly Sold to EastBanc

GM started hearing rumors a week ago about the possible sale of the historic Fillmore School building. On Friday, he heard it confirmed from reliable sources that the building was in fact sold.

Have you done any renovations lately? You may have issues with drywall made in China

Not to be an alarmist, but if you have had any renovation work done in the past few years, you may want to at least investigate what kind of drywall was used in your project.

A process painter, Dan Treado finds his inspiration in evolutionary biology.

Kitty Kelley Gets Proper…

…Topper that is.

Baby You Can Park My Car

Cars are great inventions….SO much faster than pony express, and horse and buggy, and perhaps a little easier on the street cleaners. Until, however, they make them so they can be folded and popped into our pockets, they will need to go somewhere—hence parking lots and spaces.

Good news about "Growth"!

Stephen Fuller, an economist and faculty chair at George Mason University, comments regularly on the DC Metro economy. His latest report, "The Future of the Washington Metropolitan Area Economy," is at the same time upbeat and cautionary.

Forever Lily Debuts at Apres Peau

Inspired by her unexpected journey to motherhood, Beth Nonte Russell created the fragrance line, “Forever Lily” (recently nominated for a ‘Fifi’, the fragrance industry’s answer to Oscar) and wrote a book.

ANC May Preview: Drink Up Edition

ANC2E will meet for its May session next Monday night at 6:30 at Visitation. If you like long discussions over liquor licenses, this is your month. Oh and streetcars!
